article.title: The MOSDEF survey: the prevalence and properties of galaxy-wide AGN-driven outflows at $z∼2$

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows 1D spectra of 13 AGN outflows. Which colored curve represents the best-fit narrow-line component of the emission lines?
choices: Red
Blue
Cyan
Magenta

multiple_choice_question.text: What information do the thin gray lines in each panel represent?
choices: The best-fit total emission line profile
The observed spectra
The best-fit outflow component
The best-fit broad-line component

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of emission line is represented in the leftmost panel of each row?
choices: Hα
Hβ
[OIII]
[NII]

multiple_choice_question.text: Why are there no dashed cyan curves in the spectra of AEGIS 30014, AEGIS 31250, and UDS 6055?
choices: These AGN do not have broad-line components.
The signal-to-noise ratio is too low to detect broad-line components.
The broad-line components are completely absorbed by dust.
These AGN are located at higher redshifts where broad-line components are not observed.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of this figure show?
choices: The distribution of outflow maximum velocity (vmax)
The distribution of velocity widths (FWHM) and velocity offsets (∆v) for the AGN outflows
The correlation between outflow maximum velocity (vmax) and AGN luminosity
The comparison of w80 in [OIII] to vmax in the outflow sample

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the median velocity offset (∆v) of the AGN outflows?
Based on the right panel, what is the approximate range of the maximum velocity (vmax) of the outflows?
What general trend can be observed in the left panel regarding the relationship between velocity shifts (∆v) and FWHM?
choices: Outflows with high velocity shifts (∆v) tend to have relatively low FWHM.
Outflows with high FWHM tend to have relatively low velocity shifts (∆v).
Outflows with high velocity shifts (∆v) tend to have relatively high FWHM.
There is no apparent relationship between velocity shifts (∆v) and FWHM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the magenta line represent in the left panel?
choices: The Kauffmann et al. (2003) demarcation line
The star formation main sequence for MOSDEF galaxies
The Kewley et al. (2013b) demarcation line at z=2.3
The median SFR of AGN host galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from this figure regarding the incidence of AGN outflows?
choices: Outflows are only detected in AGN above the star formation main sequence.
Outflows are more common in AGN with higher SFR.
Outflows are more common in AGN with higher stellar mass.
Outflows are detected in AGN spanning the main sequence with no clear dependence on stellar mass or SFR.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the blue and red points represent in the left panel?
choices: Blue: Galaxies; Red: AGN
Blue: AGN; Red: AGN with outflows
Blue: Star-forming galaxies; Red: Quasars
Blue: Quasars; Red: AGN with outflows

multiple_choice_question.text: What does a two-sample KS test on the stellar mass distributions of AGN with and without outflows reveal?
choices: A significant difference, suggesting a strong dependence of outflow incidence on stellar mass.
No significant difference, suggesting no clear trend of outflow incidence with host stellar mass.
A positive correlation, indicating that outflows are more common in higher mass AGN.
A negative correlation, indicating that outflows are more common in lower mass AGN.
The electron density of the ionized gas in the outflow
The mass outflow rate of the ionized gas
The kinetic energy of the ionized outflow
The mass of the ionized gas in the outflow

multiple_choice_question.text: What assumption is made about the gas in this equation?
choices: It is purely collisionally ionized.
It is in \'Case A\' recombination.
It has an electron temperature of T=10,000K.
It is primarily composed of neutral hydrogen.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the value of LHα,out in this equation?
choices: The electron density of the outflow
The outflow Hα luminosity
The outflow Hβ luminosity
The bolometric AGN luminosity

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the estimated ionized gas mass change if the electron density (ne) decreases by a factor of ten?
choices: The mass decreases by a factor of ten.
The mass remains the same.
The mass increases by a factor of ten.
The mass increases by a factor of two.
